title: Therapeutic Privacy Impact Assessment
description: A comprehensive assessment evaluating how privacy practices affect therapeutic relationships, patient agency, and clinical outcomes in healthcare settings

dualTrackGuidance.title: Dual-Track Evaluation: Compliance AND Therapeutic Impact
dualTrackGuidance.description: This assessment employs a dual-track approach recognizing that legal compliance is necessary but insufficient for therapeutic privacy practice. Track 1 evaluates whether privacy practices meet Ontario legislative requirements (PHIPA, FIPPA, MFIPPA). Track 2 evaluates whether those same practices produce therapeutic or anti-therapeutic consequences for patients, providers, and institutional relationships. A practice can be fully compliant yet anti-therapeutic, or therapeutically beneficial yet legally incomplete. The goal is alignment: practices that satisfy legal obligations WHILE maximizing therapeutic outcomes.

tracks.name: Compliance Track
tracks.question: Does this practice satisfy the requirements of PHIPA and applicable Ontario privacy legislation?
tracks.focus: Legal obligations, regulatory compliance, risk mitigation

tracks.name: Therapeutic Track
tracks.question: Does this practice produce therapeutic or anti-therapeutic consequences for those it affects?
tracks.focus: Trust, agency, safety, dignity, relational boundaries, clinician well-being, equity, clinical outcomes

sections.title: Trust Formation & Therapeutic Alliance
sections.description: Evaluate how privacy practices impact the development and maintenance of trust between patients and healthcare providers

questions.text: How do current privacy practices signal respect for patient boundaries?
questions.guidance: Consider whether privacy practices create visible boundaries, whether patients understand how their information is protected, and whether there are mechanisms for patients to voice concerns

questions.text: Do patients feel safe disclosing sensitive information necessary for diagnosis and treatment?
questions.guidance: Look for evidence of diagnostic gaps, treatment delays, or incomplete histories that may stem from privacy concerns

questions.text: Have there been privacy breaches or near-misses that eroded therapeutic relationships?
questions.guidance: Consider both actual breaches and perceived violations that affected patient confidence

questions.text: Would patients feel safer or more vulnerable because of this practice?
questions.guidance: Consider the practice from the patient's perspective—does it create a sense of protection or exposure? Think about how a patient first encountering this practice would experience it emotionally.

questions.text: Could this practice inadvertently breach patient trust, even without a formal privacy violation?
options: Moderate risk — some patients may feel uncomfortable
Low risk — practice is generally trust-supportive
No risk — practice actively reinforces trust
questions.guidance: Trust breaches can occur without legal breaches. Consider whether the practice feels respectful, whether patients understand it, and whether it aligns with patient expectations about how their information is handled.

therapeuticLens: Trust is foundational to therapeutic relationships
Privacy practices are visible signals of respect
Breaches have cascading effects beyond information disclosure

sections.title: Patient Agency & Control
sections.description: Assess whether privacy practices empower patients to exercise meaningful control over their narrative and information

questions.text: Do patients have meaningful participation in decisions about information sharing?
questions.guidance: Agency is not blanket secrecy but meaningful control. Evaluate consent processes, information governance discussions, and patient understanding

questions.text: Can patients easily access, correct, or understand their own health information?
questions.guidance: Consider both formal access rights and practical barriers to exercising them

questions.text: Are there processes for patients to express privacy preferences beyond standard consent?
questions.guidance: Describe mechanisms for patients to indicate specific privacy concerns, partial disclosures, or contextual sharing preferences

questions.text: Is consent genuine or bureaucratic ritual?

scale.minLabel: Pure ritual — patients sign without understanding
scale.maxLabel: Genuinely informed — patients understand and choose

questions.guidance: Evaluate whether consent processes achieve actual patient understanding or merely produce signed forms. Does the patient know what they agreed to? Could they explain it back? (Anti-Therapeutic Pattern #2: Bureaucratic Rituals)

questions.text: Can patients change their mind about information sharing without negative consequences?
options: No — once consent is given, it cannot be withdrawn easily
Possible with moderate effort and no negative consequences
Easy to modify or withdraw consent at any time with full support
questions.guidance: True agency requires the ability to change course. Consider whether withdrawing consent affects care quality, provider attitudes, or access to services. PHIPA s.17 lockbox rights should be practically accessible, not merely theoretically available.

therapeuticLens: Agency enables autonomy, not just protects it
Control over narrative is control over identity
Participation in governance reduces powerlessness

sections.title: Psychological Safety & Vulnerability
sections.description: Examine whether privacy practices create conditions for the emotional vulnerability necessary in therapeutic contexts

questions.text: Do privacy practices create safe spaces for discussing stigmatized conditions?
questions.guidance: Consider mental health, substance use, sexual health, and other potentially stigmatized areas

questions.text: Are there physical/environmental privacy protections during sensitive conversations?
questions.guidance: Evaluate physical spaces, soundproofing, visual privacy, and conversation locations

questions.text: How do staff behaviors and attitudes reinforce or undermine privacy safety?
questions.guidance: Consider hallway conversations, electronic device usage in public areas, casual information sharing, and respect for closed doors/curtains

questions.text: Could this practice trigger trauma or psychological harm for patients?
questions.guidance: Consider patients with histories of abuse, institutional harm, or medical trauma. Does the practice account for re-traumatization risks? Is it implemented with sensitivity to diverse trauma experiences?

questions.text: Does this practice create a protective environment for difficult conversations?
options: No — the practice makes difficult conversations harder
Somewhat — provides basic conditions but could be improved
Mostly — creates reasonable conditions for sensitive discussions
Yes — actively facilitates safe, supported disclosure
questions.guidance: Difficult conversations (mental health, end-of-life, substance use, sexuality, abuse) require privacy practices that create safety without creating barriers to care.

therapeuticLens: Vulnerability requires safety
Fear of disclosure creates diagnostic gaps
Privacy is both policy and practice

sections.title: Relational Boundaries & Circle of Care
sections.description: Evaluate how privacy practices define therapeutic boundaries while enabling coordinated care

questions.text: Is the 'circle of care' clearly defined and understood by all parties?
questions.guidance: Consider whether patients know who has access, whether clinicians understand their access rights, and whether there's clarity about information flow

questions.text: Do privacy practices support or hinder interdisciplinary collaboration?
questions.guidance: Evaluate balance between privacy protection and care coordination needs

questions.text: Describe how boundary violations are prevented, detected, and addressed
questions.guidance: Include technical controls, policy enforcement, staff training, and remediation processes

questions.text: Does this practice enable or inhibit therapeutic rapport?
questions.guidance: Consider whether the practice creates barriers between clinician and patient or facilitates connection. Does it support authentic therapeutic interaction or introduce awkwardness, distrust, or distance? (Anti-Therapeutic Pattern #3: Information Silos)

questions.text: Can clinicians honor this practice authentically without compromising care?
options: No — clinicians routinely work around this practice to deliver care
Mostly — the practice aligns with clinical workflow with minor friction
Yes — the practice integrates seamlessly with therapeutic care delivery
questions.guidance: Practices that clinicians cannot honor authentically will generate workarounds that may be less secure and more anti-therapeutic than the original problem. If clinicians are routinely bypassing a privacy practice, the practice needs redesign, not stricter enforcement.

therapeuticLens: Boundaries enable relationships, not restrict them
Clarity reduces ethical distress for clinicians
Circle of care should be visible, not invisible

sections.title: Dignity & Respect Signaling
sections.description: Assess how privacy practices communicate respect for persons and support human dignity

questions.text: Do privacy practices treat patients as persons with rights vs. data subjects?
questions.guidance: Consider language used, consent processes, and whether practices acknowledge individual circumstances

questions.text: Are privacy practices respectful of cultural and individual variations?
questions.guidance: Describe how practices accommodate diverse privacy norms, family structures, communication preferences, and cultural contexts

questions.text: How do privacy practices handle vulnerable populations differently?
questions.guidance: Consider children, elderly, cognitively impaired, non-English speakers, and others requiring tailored approaches

questions.text: Could this practice disproportionately harm marginalized groups?

scale.maxLabel: Practice is equity-promoting and culturally responsive

questions.guidance: Consider Indigenous communities (see IPC Decision 290 — Maamwesying), racialized populations, LGBTQ2S+ individuals, persons with disabilities, newcomers, and others who may experience privacy practices differently due to systemic factors. (Anti-Therapeutic Pattern #5: Cultural Insensitivity)

therapeuticLens: Privacy practices signal value of the person
Dignity is experienced through respect for boundaries
One-size-fits-all approaches undermine personhood

sections.title: Clinician Experience & Ethical Distress
sections.description: Examine how privacy requirements impact clinician well-being and therapeutic capacity

questions.text: Do clinicians view privacy as barrier or enabler of therapeutic care?
questions.guidance: Consider whether privacy is seen as bureaucratic burden vs. integral to patient-centered care

questions.text: How often do clinicians experience ethical distress related to privacy conflicts?
questions.guidance: Look for conflicts between privacy rules and perceived patient interests, documentation burdens, or role confusion

questions.text: Are clinicians adequately trained and supported in therapeutic privacy practices?
questions.guidance: Describe training content, ongoing support, ethics consultation availability, and confidence levels

questions.text: What workarounds might clinicians develop if privacy practices are too restrictive?
questions.guidance: Identify potential or observed workarounds (sharing passwords, verbal handoffs to avoid documentation, informal communication channels). Workarounds signal that privacy practices are misaligned with clinical reality and may create greater risks than the original practice intended to address. (Anti-Therapeutic Pattern #6: Technological Barriers)

therapeuticLens: Clinician well-being affects therapeutic capacity
Privacy as burden reduces therapeutic effectiveness
Clear frameworks reduce ethical distress

sections.title: Systemic Justice & Equity
sections.description: Evaluate whether privacy practices promote or hinder equitable access and fair treatment

questions.text: Are privacy protections equitably applied across all patient populations?
questions.guidance: Consider whether certain groups receive greater scrutiny, reduced privacy, or differential treatment

questions.text: Do privacy practices inadvertently create barriers to care access?
questions.guidance: Identify whether consent requirements, documentation processes, or information-sharing restrictions prevent or delay care for specific populations

questions.text: How are power imbalances addressed in privacy decision-making?
questions.guidance: Consider institutional power vs. patient agency, clinician authority vs. patient autonomy, and mechanisms for balancing these dynamics

questions.text: Do privacy practices accommodate cultural and contextual privacy needs?

scale.maxLabel: Flexibly designed for diverse cultural contexts

questions.guidance: Consider whether practices accommodate collectivist family decision-making, Indigenous governance structures, religious considerations, and other cultural contexts. Howieson's procedural justice framework emphasizes that individuals must perceive processes as fair — cultural accommodation is essential to procedural justice.

therapeuticLens: Justice requires equal information governance
Privacy protections should not create new inequities
Power imbalances shape privacy experiences

sections.title: Therapeutic Outcomes & Clinical Impact
sections.description: Connect privacy practices to measurable therapeutic and clinical outcomes

questions.text: Can you identify cases where privacy practices improved therapeutic outcomes?
questions.guidance: Provide specific examples where respecting privacy enhanced disclosure, treatment adherence, or patient engagement

questions.text: Can you identify cases where privacy practices hindered therapeutic outcomes?
questions.guidance: Provide specific examples where privacy barriers delayed diagnosis, prevented coordination, or impaired treatment

questions.text: How are privacy-related therapeutic impacts currently measured or monitored?
questions.guidance: Consider existing quality indicators, patient feedback mechanisms, and outcome tracking

questions.text: Are there alternative approaches that maintain compliance while enhancing therapeutic outcomes?
questions.guidance: For each anti-therapeutic practice identified in earlier sections, consider whether an alternative implementation could satisfy the same legal requirement while producing better therapeutic outcomes. Campbell's TJ framing asks: 'Could the same protective goals be achieved through less therapeutically harmful means?'

therapeuticLens: Privacy is clinical variable affecting outcomes
Therapeutic impact should be measured
Data should inform continuous improvement

scoringGuidance.interpretation: This assessment uses a dual-track evaluation. For quantitative questions (scale and select), responses map to a therapeutic impact score from +2 (Strongly Therapeutic) to -2 (Strongly Anti-Therapeutic) per dimension.

scoringScale.description: Each dimension receives a therapeutic impact score based on aggregated responses:

levels.label: Strongly Therapeutic
levels.description: Practices actively build trust, empower patients, and enhance clinical outcomes beyond compliance requirements

levels.label: Therapeutic
levels.description: Practices generally support therapeutic relationships while meeting legal obligations

levels.label: Neutral/Mixed
levels.description: Practices meet compliance requirements but have mixed or unclear therapeutic impact

levels.label: Anti-Therapeutic
levels.description: Practices are legally compliant but undermine trust, agency, or therapeutic relationships

levels.label: Strongly Anti-Therapeutic
levels.description: Practices actively harm therapeutic relationships, erode trust, or disempower patients, even if technically compliant

overallCategories.description: Privacy practices are deeply therapeutic, exceeding compliance requirements and actively strengthening care relationships
Privacy practices generally support therapeutic relationships with opportunities for further enhancement
Privacy practices meet compliance but have inconsistent therapeutic impact — requires targeted improvements
Privacy practices are undermining therapeutic relationships despite legal compliance — significant redesign needed
Privacy practices are actively causing harm to therapeutic relationships — urgent intervention required

nextSteps: Identify anti-therapeutic practices requiring immediate attention (score -1 or below)
Recognize therapeutic strengths to build upon (score +1 or above)
For each anti-therapeutic practice, identify alternative implementations that maintain compliance while improving therapeutic outcomes
Develop action plan addressing key gaps with specific timelines and responsible parties
Establish ongoing monitoring mechanisms using this assessment as a baseline
Engage stakeholders in collaborative improvement — patients, clinicians, administrators, and privacy officers
Re-assess at regular intervals (recommended: annually, or after significant policy changes)
